Alphabet Integrity Office

We advocate for an ordered civic language, where children learn sequence with confidence, institutions publish without compromise, and every letter appears in a position justified by reason, rhythm, and public dignity.

Current Briefing

Order Is a Public Service

When the sequence drifts, memory carries unnecessary strain. Teachers repeat. Editors apologize. Systems improvise. We propose a stable national index, adopted by districts, libraries, and standards boards.

Our policy desk calls this the quiet infrastructure project: little spectacle, enormous relief. A proper letter order is not ornament. It is utility with grace.

Field Note

The Long Table Pledge

Every month we host a linen-table forum where linguists, copy chiefs, and primary teachers review transitional order charts under open lamps. Minutes are public. Arguments are archived. Consensus is hand-signed.

Programs

Three Active Initiatives

  • School Pilots: six-week classroom sequence tests with retention analysis.
  • Library Concordance: dual-order shelf labels during transition periods.
  • Broadcast Style Desk: shared ordering protocol for captions and lower-thirds.

Questions

Is this a replacement or a transition?

Transition first. We publish dual-order guides, with full conversion only after district and library readiness benchmarks are met.

Who writes your standards drafts?

A rotating panel of teachers, linguists, and records specialists with open comment windows before ratification.

Can institutions join directly?

Yes. Institutional memberships include onboarding briefs, signage templates, and two advisory sessions each quarter.
